statement.tex: %text One kind of cake requires 300g of flour and 15g of fat, another kind of cake requires 150g of flour and 30g of fat. Find the maximum number of cakes which can be made from 7.5 kg of flour and 600g of fat, assuming that there is no shortage of other imgredients used in making cakes. Make it as a LPP and solve it graphically. %

\\ %text If $N_A$ and $N_B$ be the number of the two types of cakes made, then are the following conditions on $N_A$ and $N_B$ correct? % \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Cake} & \text{Flour} & \text{Fat} \\ \hline A & 300g & 15g \\ \hline B & 150g & 30g \\ \hline \end{tabular}
\\ %text Given the constraints on $N_A$ and $N_B$, does the figure below correctly show the \underline\text{feasible region}? %
\\ %text Given the feasible region, which of the points (A-E) represents the point with maximum number of cakes? %

reason.tex:
%text We have only 7.5kg of flour and 600g of fat available to make the cakes. Therefore,
% \begin{align} \underbrace{(300g)\cdot N_A + (150g)\cdot N_B }_{\text{Flour}}&\leq \underbrace{7500g}_{=7.5 kg}\\ \implies 2N_A + N_B &\leq 50 \\ \underbrace{(15g)\cdot N_A + (30g)\cdot N_B}_{\text{Fat}} &\leq 600g \\ \implies N_A + 2N_B &\leq 40 \end{align} \\ \underline\text{Be mindful of the units (kg or gm)!}

%text The two lines we need to plot are % \begin{align} 2N_A + N_B &= 50\text{ (line BD)} \\ N_A + 2N_B &= 40\text{ (line AE)} \end{align} \\ %text
And you can confirm that the end-points of these lines are as follows
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Point} & A & B & D & E \\ \hline (N_A,N_B) & (0,20) & (0,50) & (25,0) & (40,0) \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text
Notice, however, that any \underline\text{feasible point} must lie \underline\text{below both the lines}.
Hence, the \underline\text{feasible region} is one which includes points like point $\dot p$. %

%text The feasible region from the last step gives us \underline\text{three candidates points} - A,C and D.
The coordinates of \underline\text{point C} can be found by solving the following equations %
\begin{align} 2N_A + N_B &= 50 \\ N_A + 2N_B &= 40 \\ \implies N_A &= 20\text{ and }N_B = 10 \end{align}
%text And therefore, %
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Point} & \text{Coordinates} & \text{# cakes} = N_A + N_B \\ \hline A & (0,20) & 20 \\ \hline C & (20,10) & 30 \\ \hline D & (25,0) & 25 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text
Hence, the largest number of cakes we can make with the given supplies is 30. %
